Even if they could succeed in making the phones secure, the networks aren't secure.
And there is no such thing as a purely open source phone. The baseband software will never be open source.
I suspect that if you run an up to date version of Android without all the crapware that vendors pile onto it, Android is as secure as anything else you might run.
At least, anything with actual functionality.
The main issue with Android security is that there are a lot of people running old versions and vendors installing crapware and then not patching it.
Relying on carriers to get around to issuing patches, and on users to apply them, is a losing battle. I know people who won't apply patches because they're worried about them breaking things.
Because of course vendors never issue patches that only fix security bugs.
I know of many a "no-op" change that has resulted in breakage.

This is why we need systems like Nix, where you can roll back to a known-good state at any time. Harder to do with data, though, since it's not like you can automatically revert newly-written data to the old schema.
If the API is forward compatible you could log the operations and reapply them after rolling back, I guess. That's also very hard to do generically, though.
Most data is not stored relationally with a schema, though. Most of it is "document-store" style, where you could use json or xml and just ignore fields you don't recognize.
rooting your android is not a good way to keep it secure, though
nor is unlocking the bootloader
there are a bunch of copy-on-write and log-structured filesystems.
ZFS and BtrFS are both copy-on-write
you can't roll back to any point in time but snapshots are incredibly cheap
ubuntu is supposedly getting native support for zfs
Which I assume means the installer

zfs also makes it pretty cheap to make new containers, but you need block deduplication to keep your containers from taking up more and more space as you update them. Assuming you update them through the normal means and not by updating a "golden container" and then re-cloning all your other containers each time.

you could do something similar with nix since nix never actually changes anything, so every version you've ever installed remains available until it's garbage collected after no longer being referred to by any configuration
but nix requires more modifications to packages in order to get them to play nice
separate filesystems are also very cheap with zfs, so you could actually have a filesystem per package
then use some kind of union filesystem to control which packages each container can see, kind of like tinycore does
I guess docker does that too, but for emulating copy-on-write
I really like the idea of a system with the immutability of nix but that's transparent to the applications
I don't know how you'd handle overlapping dependencies, though. Nix doesn't care if you mix versions other than your normal symbol versioning problems

But maybe that's a bad enough problem that you shouldn't allow mutually conflicting dependencies within a single container anyway. Nix pretends that problem doesn't exist, but intuitively it seems like you really can't.

It seems unlikely to me that they're intentionally making older models slower. More likely they just reduce the testing they do on older models to basic smoke tests and not performance tests.
If you're writing software for newer, more capable platforms, it's inevitable that it will run slower and slower on older platforms.
Obviously this also works to their advantage, but given that they'd have to go out of their way not to do it, it seems silly to attribute it to some kind of sneaky agenda.
The fact of the matter is you don't really "buy" an iPhone (or any handset really)
You're really just renting Apple & AT&T
And the phone you think you "bought" is really just an accessory to Apple's software, which is a moving target, and AT&T's network

It's like how you still have to pay a huge payment up front for the privilege of leasing land in many countries, even though you don't actually own the land, you just have a 30 year lease or something

If you really want computing hardware that will last a long time, you better have a vendor that you can trust to issue security fixes without throwing in a bunch of new features without caring about perf regressions
Linux generally is in this category. GNOME, not so much. Though there are plenty of lightweight forks and lightweight desktops/window managers
Android is probably a better OS for this purpose than iOS since there are so many low-end devices being sold even today.
